questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding and discomfort during bowel movements. On examination, he is diagnosed with hemorrhoids. Which of the following best describes internal hemorrhoids?
questions.solution:
Haemorrhoids

  • Symptomatic enlargements of anal cushions, commonly seen with raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., constipation, pregnancy).
  • Locations: Typically found at the 3, 7, and 11 o'clock positions (lithotomy position).
  • Symptoms:
    • Bright-red, painless bleeding, pruritus, mucus discharge, and prolapse.
  • Four Degrees of Haemorrhoids:
  • First degree: Bleeding without prolapse.
  • Second degree: Prolapse with spontaneous reduction.
  • Third degree: Prolapse requiring manual reduction.
  • Fourth degree: Permanently prolapsed.
  • Complications:
    • Strangulation and thrombosis
    • Ulceration
    • Gangrene
    • Portal pyaemia

Explanation:

Option A: Incorrect. External hemorrhoids are covered by skin.

Option B: Correct. Internal hemorrhoids are located above the pectinate line and are typically associated with painless bleeding.

Option C: Incorrect. Internal hemorrhoids are located above the pectinate line, while external hemorrhoids are below.

Option D: Incorrect. External hemorrhoids are often painful when thrombosed.

Key points:

Internal hemorrhoids are above the pectinate line, covered by mucosa, and associated with painless bleeding, while external hemorrhoids are below the pectinate line and covered by skin.

choices.text: Supplied by the inferior rectal artery
Drains to internal iliac lymph nodes

questions.text: A patient presents with rectal pain and a mass in the anal canal. You are asked to assess whether the lesion is above or below the pectinate line. Which of the following is true regarding the features of the anal canal below the pectinate line?
questions.solution:
Anatomy and Physiology of the Anal Canal

  • Internal sphincter: Composed of involuntary, non-striated muscle, supplied by autonomic nerves.
  • External sphincter: Composed of voluntary, striated muscle, supplied by the pudendal nerve.
  • Intersphincteric plane: Space between the internal and external sphincters.
  • Puborectalis muscle: Fuses with the superior part of the external sphincter, crucial for maintaining the anorectal angle for continence.
  • Epithelium: Lower part of the anal canal is lined by sensitive squamous epithelium.
  • Blood supply: Via superior, middle, and inferior rectal vessels.
  • Lymphatic drainage: Lower half drains to inguinal lymph nodes.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Correct. The area below the pectinate line is supplied by the inferior rectal artery.

Option B: Incorrect. The area below the pectinate line is lined by stratified squamous epithelium, while above the line is lined by columnar epithelium.

Option C: Incorrect. The area below the pectinate line is innervated by somatic afferents, leading to sensitivity to pain, touch, and temperature.

Option D: Incorrect. The area below the pectinate line drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, while the area above drains to the internal iliac nodes.

Key Points:

  • The puborectalis muscle and anorectal angle are essential for continence. Both sphincters have distinct functions and innervations.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of diverticulitis presents with fever, abdominal pain, and peritonitis. Imaging reveals free air in the peritoneal cavity. According to Hinchey's classification, what is the stage of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. Stage I involves a pericolic or mesenteric abscess.

Option B: Incorrect. Stage II involves a pelvic or distant abscess.

Option C: Incorrect. Stage III involves purulent peritonitis.

Option D: Correct. Stage IV involves fecal peritonitis, as seen with free air or fecal matter in the peritoneal cavity.

choices.text: At least 2 family members with colorectal cancer
At least 3 family members with an associated cancer (colorectal, endometrial, small bowel)
The diagnosis of colorectal cancer in at least 1 individual under 70 years of age
Presence of adenomatous polyps in family members

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a strong family history of colorectal cancer. Based on the Amsterdam II criteria, which of the following is a necessary condition to diagnose Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)?
questions.solution:
Lynch Syndrome (HNPCC)

  • Autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2).
  • Increased cancer risk: Colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, stomach, small intestine, urinary tract, pancreas, prostate, kidney.
  • Lifetime risk: 80% for colorectal cancer, 30-50% for endometrial cancer.
  • Diagnosis: Based on family history, Amsterdam/Bethesda criteria, immunohistochemistry for MMR proteins, and genetic testing.
  • Management: Regular endoscopic surveillance (2-yearly from age 25 for MLH1/MSH2, 5-yearly for PMS2), extended colectomy if needed.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. The criteria require at least 3 family members with cancer.

Option B: Correct. The Amsterdam II criteria require 3 or more family members with cancers associated with HNPCC (e.g., colorectal, endometrial).

Option C: Incorrect. Colorectal cancer must occur in at least 1 individual under 50 years of age.

Option D: Incorrect. The presence of adenomatous polyps alone is not a criterion for HNPCC diagnosis.

Key points:

  • The Amsterdam II criteria include 3 relatives with associated cancers, 1 diagnosed before age 50, and involvement of at least 2 generations. (3,2,1)

questions.text: A 62-year-old female is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. The tumor is found to invade the muscularis propria without lymph node involvement. According to Dukes' classification, what is the stage of this cancer?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. Dukes A involves cancer confined to the mucosa and submucosa.

Option B: Correct. Dukes B involves cancer extending through the muscularis propria without lymph node involvement.

Option C: Incorrect. Dukes C involves lymph node involvement.

Option D: Incorrect. Dukes D involves distant metastasis.

Key points:

  • Dukes A involves mucosa/submucosa, Dukes B involves muscularis propria, Dukes C includes lymph node involvement, and Dukes D involves metastasis.

choices.text: Watchful waiting, as the polyp will likely resolve spontaneously
Removal of the polyp via forceps or snare if symptomatic

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with painless rectal bleeding. On examination, a bright red, pedunculated polyp is seen prolapsing during defecation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Juvenile polyp

  • A benign, pedunculated polyp found in children, often presenting with painless rectal bleeding.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic polyps can be easily removed using forceps or a snare.
  • Malignancy risk: Solitary juvenile polyps have no malignant potential, but multiple polyps seen in juvenile polyposis syndrome carry a risk of malignancy.
  • The rare autosomal dominant inherited syndrome juvenile polyposis does carry an increased risk of malignancy. It is characterized by multiple polyps and a positive family history.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Watchful waiting: Incorrect. While some juvenile polyps may resolve spontaneously, symptomatic polyps causing bleeding or prolapse should be treated.

Option B. Immediate surgical resection: Incorrect. Surgical resection is rarely necessary; most juvenile polyps can be easily removed using forceps or a snare.

Option C. Removal of the polyp via forceps or snare if symptomatic: Correct. Symptomatic juvenile polyps can be removed using forceps or a snare during a simple procedure.

Option D. Colonoscopy screening for multiple polyps: Incorrect. This is recommended for patients with juvenile polyposis syndrome, not for solitary juvenile polyps.

Key notes: Symptomatic polyps (prolapse or bleeding ) undergo removal via snare or forceps

choices.text: Colorectal cancer in a patient under 60 years of age with mucinous histology
Colorectal cancer in a patient over 70 years of age with a family history
A single adenomatous polyp diagnosed at age 40

questions.text: A patient with a family history of colorectal cancer is being evaluated for Lynch syndrome. Based on the Bethesda criteria, which of the following is an indication for microsatellite instability (MSI) testing?
questions.solution:
Bethesda criteria for testing colorectal tumors

  1. Colorectal cancer diagnosed before the age of 50.
  1. Presence of synchronous/metachronous colorectal or other hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)-related tumors, including endometrial, stomach, ovarian, pancreas, ureter, renal pelvis, biliary tract, brain, sebaceous gland adenomas, and keratoacanthomas.
  1. Colorectal cancer with MSI-H histology(tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, Crohn's-like lymphocytic reaction, mucinous/signet-ring differentiation, or medullary growth pattern) diagnosed in a patient younger than 60 years.
  1. Colorectal cancer diagnosed in at least one first-degree relative with a Lynch-related tumor, one of which was diagnosed before age 50.
  1. Colorectal cancer diagnosed in at least two first- or second-degree relatives with HNPCC-related tumors, regardless of age.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Correct. The Bethesda criteria include colorectal cancer diagnosed under 60 years with mucinous or signet-ring histology for MSI testing.

Option B: Incorrect. Age over 70 is not a specific criterion for MSI testing in Bethesda guidelines.

Option C: Incorrect. Adenomatous polyps are not directly included in the Bethesda criteria.

Option D: Incorrect. The family history of colorectal cancer or associated cancers (e.g., endometrial) is relevant, not prostate cancer.

Key points:

  • The Bethesda criteria identify patients for MSI testing, including young patients with colorectal cancer and mucinous histology or a family history of HNPCC-related cancers.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with prolapsing hemorrhoids that can be manually reduced. According to the grading system for hemorrhoids, what grade does this represent?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhoids

  • Symptomatic enlargements of anal cushions, commonly seen with raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., constipation, pregnancy).
  • Locations: Typically found at the 3, 7, and 11 o'clock positions (lithotomy position).
  • Symptoms:
    • Bright-red, painless bleeding, pruritus, mucus discharge, and prolapse.
  • Four Degrees of Hemorrhoids:
  • First degree: Bleeding without prolapse.
  • Second degree: Prolapse with spontaneous reduction.
  • Third degree: Prolapse requiring manual reduction.
  • Fourth degree: Permanently prolapsed.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Grade I hemorrhoids do not prolapse.

Option B: Incorrect. Grade II hemorrhoids prolapse but reduce spontaneously.

Option C: Correct. Grade III hemorrhoids prolapse but require manual reduction.

Option D: Incorrect. Grade IV hemorrhoids are irreducible and remain prolapsed.

Key points:

  • Grade III hemorrhoids prolapse and require manual reduction, while Grade IV hemorrhoids are irreducible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with Grade II hemorrhoids. She reports occasional bleeding and prolapse during defecation, which reduces spontaneously. What is the recommended initial treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhoidectomy

Indications for Surgery:

  • Third- and fourth-degree hemorrhoids
  • Second-degree hemorrhoids not responding to non-operative treatment
  • Well-defined external hemorrhoids
  • Bleeding causing anemia

Surgical Techniques:

  1. Open Technique (Milligan-Morgan):
  • Involves ligation and excision of hemorrhoids.
  • Skin and mucosa are left open to heal by secondary intention.
  • Requires careful dissection and hemostasis.
  1. Closed Technique (Ferguson):
  • Excision of hemorrhoids followed by suturing the wound closed.
  1. Stapled Hemorrhoidopexy (PPH or Longo):
  • Uses a circular stapler to remove a cylinder of mucosa and submucosa.
  • Less painful, faster recovery, but higher recurrence rates and risk of complications.
  1. Transanal Hemorrhoidal Ligation (HAL):
  • Doppler-guided ligation of vessels feeding hemorrhoids.
  • Lower recurrence than rubber band ligation with fewer complications.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Hemorrhoidectomy is typically reserved for Grade III or IV hemorrhoids or those that do not respond to less invasive treatments.

Option B: Correct. Rubber band ligation is the first-line treatment for Grade II hemorrhoids, which prolapse but reduce spontaneously.

Option C: Incorrect. Sclerotherapy is another option for Grade I or II hemorrhoids, but rubber band ligation is preferred for Grade II.

Option D: Incorrect. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is used for circumferential prolapse (Grade III or IV), not Grade II hemorrhoids.

Key points:

  • Rubber band ligation is the preferred initial treatment for Grade II hemorrhoids, which prolapse but reduce spontaneously.

choices.text: Trans-sphincteric fistulae traverse both the internal and external sphincters
Extra sphincteric fistulae pass through both the sphincter and rectal wall

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a perianal abscess, and examination reveals a complex fistula-in-Ano. Which of the following is true regarding the classification of fistula-in-Ano?
questions.solution:
Fistula Types:

  1. Intersphincteric Fistula (45%):
  • Does not cross the external sphincter.
  • Runs between internal and external openings, often within the distal internal sphincter.
  • May extend to the upper anal canal or rectum.
  1. Trans-sphincteric Fistula (40%):
  • Crosses both internal and external sphincters
  • Passes through the ischiorectal fossa to the skin.
  • May have secondary tracks or horseshoe spread.
  1. Suprasphincteric Fistula (10%):
  • Extends above the puborectalis and descends through the levator muscles.
  • Often caused by probing during examination.
  1. Extrasphincteric Fistula (5%):
  • Not related to the sphincters.
  • Usually caused by pelvic disease or trauma.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Inter-sphincteric fistulae involve only the internal sphincter and do not traverse the external sphincter.

Option B: Correct. Trans-sphincteric fistulae pass through both the internal and external sphincters.

Option C: Incorrect. Suprasphincteric fistulae pass above the external sphincter but remain within the confines of the pelvic floor.

Option D: Incorrect. Extra sphincteric fistulae pass outside the sphincter complex, but they do not pass through the rectal wall.

Key points:

  • Fistula-in-ano can be classified into inter-sphincteric, trans-sphincteric, supra sphincteric, and extra sphincteric types, depending on the location relative to the sphincters.

choices.text: It follows a straight path to the anus
It takes a curved course to the posterior midline
It follows a straight path to the anterior midline
It follows a curved course to the anterior midline

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a perianal fistula located posterior to the anal verge. According to Goodsall's rule, what is the most likely course of this fistula?
questions.solution:
• Goodsall's rule states that fistulas located posterior to the anal verge follow a curved course toward the posterior midline, while anterior fistulas follow a straight path to the anus.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Fistulas located posterior to the anal verge typically follow a curved path to the posterior midline, according to Goodsall's rule.

Option B: Correct. According to Goodsall's rule, fistulas originating posterior to the anal verge take a curved course toward the posterior midline.

Option C: Incorrect. Fistulas located anterior to the anal verge tend to take a straight path to the anterior midline.

Option D: Incorrect. Fistulas posterior to the anal verge do not follow a curved course to the anterior midline.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and constipation for 3 days. An abdominal x-ray reveals a "coffee bean" sign. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Volvulus

Twisting of the intestine and its mesentery, most commonly in the sigmoid colon but can occur in the caecum or transverse colon.

  • Common Locations:
    • Sigmoid Volvulus: Seen in elderly, institutionalized patients, but common in younger patients in West Africa.
    • Caecal Volvulus: Usually affects younger, otherwise healthy individuals.
  • Predisposing Factors: Adhesions, gastric banding, pelvic masses, and pregnancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Massive abdominal distension is the key sign. Pain indicates possible ischemia.
  • Investigation:
    • Supine abdominal radiograph (helpful but not always diagnostic).
    • CT scan is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Sigmoid Volvulus: Non-operative decompression using sigmoidoscope or colonoscope. Surgery is considered if recurrence or ischemia occurs.
    • Caecal Volvulus: Urgent right hemicolectomy; endoscopic decompression is usually ineffective.
    • Surgical Considerations: Avoid anastomosis in cases of ischemia; opt for procedures like Hartmann's or Paul-Mikulicz stoma if necessary.

Key points:

  • Sigmoid volvulus is initially managed with endoscopic decompression. Surgery is indicated for recurrent cases or if complications such as perforation arise.

questions.text: The adenoma-carcinoma sequence describes the progression of colorectal cancer from benign polyps to malignant tumors. Which genetic mutation is associated with the earliest stage of this sequence?
questions.solution:
Adenoma-Carcinoma Sequence:

  • Colorectal cancer develops from adenomatous polyps through multiple genetic mutations influenced by environmental factors.
  • Key Genetic Mutations:
    • APCGene Mutation: Occurs early in carcinogenesis, found in two-thirds of colonic adenomas.
    • K-rasMutation: Activates cell signaling pathways, more common in larger lesions, indicating later involvement in the mutation process.
    • p53 Mutation: Common in carcinomas, but not in adenomas, indicating a role in tumor invasion.
  • Consensus Molecular Subtypes (CMS):
    • CMS1: Associated with microsatellite instability (MSI), commonly seen in Lynch syndrome and right-sided tumors.
    • CMS2: Shows WNT and MYC signaling activation.
    • CMS3: Related to metabolic dysregulation.
    • CMS4: Associated with transforming growth factor-beta activation.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Correct. APC gene mutation is the initiating event in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence, leading to the formation of adenomatous polyps.

Option B: Incorrect. KRAS gene mutation occurs later, promoting polyp growth.

Option C: Incorrect. TP53 mutation occurs in the later stages of adenoma progression to carcinoma.

Option D: Incorrect. DCC gene mutation is involved in the progression from adenoma to carcinoma.

Key Notes:

The adenoma-carcinoma sequence begins with an APC gene mutation, followed by KRAS and TP53 mutations, leading to the development of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with acute abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension. A CT scan reveals a "whirl sign" in the right lower quadrant. What is the next appropriate management step?
questions.solution:
Volvulus

Twisting of the intestine and its mesentery, most commonly in the sigmoid colon but can occur in the caecum or transverse colon.

  • Common Locations:

Caecal Volvulus: Usually affects younger, otherwise healthy individuals.

  • Predisposing Factors: Adhesions, gastric banding, pelvic masses, and pregnancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Massive abdominal distension is the key sign. Pain indicates possible ischaemia.
  • Investigation:
    • Supine abdominal radiograph (helpful but not always diagnostic).
    • CT scan is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Caecal Volvulus: Urgent right hemicolectomy; endoscopic decompression is usually ineffective.

Key points:

  • Cecal volvulus is a surgical emergency that typically requires laparotomy to correct the twisted bowel and prevent complications like bowel ischemia or perforation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with complete rectal prolapse. Which of the following is a commonly recommended treatment for rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Rectal Prolapse Surgery:

Perineal Approach: Preferred for elderly, frail patients or young men to avoid nerve damage.

  • Thiersch's Operation: Involves placing a wire/tape around the anal canal, now largely obsolete due to complications (e.g., perineal sepsis).
  • Delorme's Operation: Strips rectal mucosa and plicates the muscle. High recurrence rates (30% over 5 years).
  • Altemeier's Procedure: Full thickness rectal resection through the anal canal. Used for incarcerated/strangulated prolapse but can lead to poor bowel control.

Abdominal Approach: Fixes the rectum to the sacrum. Performed open or laparoscopically.

  • Sutured Rectopexy: The rectum is sutured to the sacrum. May worsen constipation.
  • Resection Rectopexy: Adds sigmoid resection to prevent constipation but increases anastomosis risk.
  • Laparoscopic Ventral Mesh Rectopexy (LVMR):Involves placing mesh between rectum and vagina (or prostate) and securing it to the sacral promontory. Popular for preventing prolapse and reducing recurrence.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Sclerotherapy is not used for the treatment of rectal prolapse; it is typically used for hemorrhoids.

Option B: Correct. Delorme's procedure is a perineal approach to treat full-thickness rectal prolapse, especially in elderly or high-risk patients.

Option C: Incorrect. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is used for hemorrhoids, not rectal prolapse.

Option D: Incorrect. Colectomy is not the primary treatment for rectal prolapse.

Key points:

  • Delorme's procedure is often used to treat complete rectal prolapse in elderly or high-risk patients, providing a less invasive approach with good outcomes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with metastatic colorectal cancer is being treated with chemotherapy. Which of the following agents is most commonly used as a first-line treatment in metastatic colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy for Rectal Cancer

  • Chemotherapy can be combined with radiotherapy (chemoradiotherapy) to downstage tumors before surgery or used postoperatively to reduce the risk of metastasis.
  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)-based regimens are the first-line treatment, improving disease-free survival by 10% in patients with node-positive rectal cancer.
  • Second-line therapies include oxaliplatin and irinotecan.
  • Biological agents such as cetuximab are also used in treatment strategies.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Correct. 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a standard first-line chemotherapy agent for metastatic colorectal cancer, often used in combination with other drugs such as leucovorin and oxaliplatin.

Option B: Incorrect. Doxorubicin is used in other cancers, like breast cancer, but not commonly in colorectal cancer.

Option C: Incorrect. Paclitaxel is mainly used for breast and ovarian cancers.

Option D: Incorrect. Cyclophosphamide is used for hematologic cancers, not typically for colorectal cancer.

Key points:

  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is the cornerstone of chemotherapy regimens for metastatic colorectal cancer, often in combination with other agents like leucovorin and oxaliplatin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a colonoscopy, and a pedunculated polyp is found. According to Haggit's classification, which layer is involved if the polyp has not invaded beyond the stalk?
questions.solution:
Haggitt Classification of Polyp

  • The Haggitt classification is used to describe the depth of invasion of malignant polyps in the colon, specifically when carcinoma invades through the muscularis mucosa but does not involve the muscularis propria.
  • It is divided into four levels:
  1. Level 0: Carcinoma in situ, or intramucosal carcinoma (no invasion of the muscularis mucosa).
  2. Level 1: Invasion into the submucosa but limited to the head of the polyp.
  3. Level 2: Invasion into the neck of the polyp.
  4. Level 3: Invasion into any part of the stalk of the polyp.
  5. Level 4: Invasion beyond the stalk into the submucosa of the bowel wall but above the muscularis propria.
  • Clinical significance: Levels 1-3 can often be treated with endoscopic polypectomy if complete removal is achieved, while Level 4 may require more extensive surgical intervention.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Level 1 refers to invasion confined to the head of the polyp.

Option B: Incorrect. Level 2 refers to invasion into the neck of the polyp.

Option C: Correct. Level 3 refers to invasion into the stalk of the polyp but not beyond.

Option D: Incorrect. Level 4 refers to invasion beyond the stalk into the submucosa.

Key points:

  • Haggit's classification describes the depth of invasion in pedunculated polyps, with Level 3 involving the stalk but not the submucosa.

choices.text: Initiate endoscopic surveillance from the age of 35 years
Referral to medical geneticist and initiate surveillance at the age of 12-14 years

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents for evaluation after his father was diagnosed with multiple polyps. Genetic testing confirms that the patient has a mutation in the APC gene. What is the next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)

  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the APC gene, with a lifetime risk of colorectal cancer close to 100%.
  • Clinical Features:
    • > 100 colorectal adenomas typically seen by age 15-30 years.
    • Extracolonic manifestations include duodenal adenomas, desmoid tumors, osteomas, and retinal pigment hypertrophy (CHRPE).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Genetic testing for APC mutations.
    • Regular endoscopy from age 12-14 years for high-risk individuals.
  • Treatment:
    • Prophylactic surgery to prevent colorectal cancer: options include restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis, colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis, or total proctocolectomy with ileostomy.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Initiate colonoscopic surveillance immediately: Incorrect. Colonoscopic surveillance typically begins at the age of 12-14 years unless there are symptoms.

Option B: Schedule a prophylactic colectomy immediately: Incorrect. Surgery is usually deferred until later adolescence unless symptoms develop or a large number of polyps are detected.

Option C: Initiate endoscopic surveillance from the age of 35 years: Incorrect. Surveillance should start earlier, by age 12-14 years, given the high risk of developing polyps early.

Option D: Referral to medical geneticist and initiate surveillance at the age of 12-14 years: Correct. Early surveillance is crucial due to the early onset of polyps in FAP patients. A medical geneticist is needed for family assessment and further counseling.

Key Points:

  • APC gene mutation causes multiple colorectal adenomas. Surgery aims to prevent colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with pruritus and small, pinkish-white lesions around the anal margin. He has a history of multiple sexual partners. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Condylomata Acuminata (Anal Warts)

  • This are caused by sexually transmitted infection with human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly subtypes 16,18,31 and 33.
  • These subtypes are associated with anal intraepithelial neoplasia (AIN) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the anus.
  • Presentation:
    • Patients may present with pruritus, discharge, bleeding, or pain.
    • Examination reveals pinkish-white warts around the anal margin, which may coalesce and carpet the area in more severe cases.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by biopsy and can be aided by aceto-whitening using acetic acid.
  • Treatment:
    • Includes podophyllin application for perianal warts
    • intra-anal warts require surgical excision with electrocautery or scissors.

Explanation of Options:

(A) Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Incorrect. While HIV can cause immunosuppression and increase the risk of HPV-related lesions, it is not the primary causative agent of anal warts.

(B) Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): Incorrect. EBV is associated with lymphoproliferative diseases, not anal warts.

(C) Human papillomavirus (HPV): Correct. HPV, particularly subtypes 16, 18, 31, and 33, is the causative agent of condylomata acuminata (anal warts), which can lead to anal intraepithelial neoplasia (AIN) and squamous cell carcinoma.

(D) Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Incorrect. CMV is associated with gastrointestinal ulcerations and colitis in immunocompromised individuals but does not cause anal warts.

Key Points:

  • HPV is the causative agent for anal warts, AIN, and SCC. Associated subtypes: HPV 16, 18, 31, and 33 carry a higher risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with recurrent pain and swelling in the sacrococcygeal region, along with occasional discharge of pus. Examination reveals an abscess near the intergluteal cleft. What is the most likely diagnosis, and the initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pilonidal sinus - Incision and drainage: Correct. Pilonidal sinus commonly presents as a painful abscess or chronic drainage in the sacrococcygeal region. The initial treatment in the acute setting is incision and drainage.

Option B: Perianal abscess - Oral antibiotics: Incorrect. While perianal abscess may present with pain and discharge, it is located closer to the anal margin, and oral antibiotics alone are insufficient without drainage.

Option C: Anal fistula - Fistulotomy: Incorrect. Anal fistulas are characterized by abnormal connections between the anal canal and perianal skin, not in the sacrococcygeal region.

Option D: Infected sebaceous cyst - Excision: Incorrect. Infected sebaceous cysts are treated by excision but are not typically located in the sacrococcygeal region or associated with a sinus tract.

Pilonidal sinus

  • Condition in the natal cleft with midline openings leading to a fibrous track containing loose hair.
  • Etiology: Acquired from friction and shearing forces. Common in hirsute men post-puberty, with occupational links like in hairdressers.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine. Recurrent abscesses are common, and sinuses are midline.
  • Conservative Treatment: Hair removal, hygiene, and occasional cauterization or laser treatment.
  • Acute Abscess: Incision and drainage, with curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical Treatment:
  • Techniques: Laying open, excision, or flap procedures (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis).
  • Bascom's Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus, followed by midline closure.

Key points: Pilonidal sinus commonly presents as a painful abscess or chronic drainage in the sacrococcygeal region.

choices.text: Laparoscopic anterior resection has a higher recurrence rate than open surgery
Laparoscopic surgery leads to quicker recovery and improved cosmesis
Laparoscopic anterior resection cannot be combined with splenic flexure mobilization
Laparoscopic approach requires a complete laparotomy incision for bowel resection

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of rectal cancer in the lower third of the rectum undergoes laparoscopic anterior resection. Which of the following is true about the laparoscopic approach compared to open surgery?
questions.solution:
Anterior Resection

  • Purpose: To treat tumors of the middle and lower rectum while preserving the anal sphincter, reducing the need for permanent colostomy.
  • Approach: Can be performed using open, laparoscopic, or robotic surgery. Laparoscopic and robotic approaches offer benefits like less pain, quicker recovery, and improved cosmesis.
  • Surgical Steps:
    • Midline abdominal incision for open surgery.
    • Mobilization of sigmoid and descending colon.
    • Protection of ureter and blood vessels during mobilization.
    • Dissection of the rectum in embryological planes with nerve preservation (total mesorectal excision).
    • Division of rectum and colon with a stapling device.
    • High tie of the inferior mesenteric artery at its aortic origin.
    • Bowel continuity is restored using a double or single stapling technique or a hand-sewn anastomosis for low anastomoses.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Laparoscopic anterior resection has a higher recurrence rate than open surgery: Incorrect. Current evidence suggests that laparoscopic surgery is as safe as open surgery in terms of oncological outcomes.

Option B: Laparoscopic surgery leads to quicker recovery and improved cosmesis: Correct. Laparoscopic techniques offer less abdominal access trauma, leading to faster recovery and better cosmetic outcomes.

Option C Laparoscopic anterior resection cannot be combined with splenic flexure mobilization: Incorrect. Laparoscopic anterior resection includes splenic flexure mobilization for a tension-free colorectal anastomosis.

Option D: Laparoscopic approach requires a complete laparotomy incision for bowel resection: Incorrect. A small laparotomy is still required for specimen extraction, but it is much smaller than a complete laparotomy.

Key points:

  • Anterior resection aims to spare the sphincter and avoid permanent colostomy in rectal cancer patients.

Clamp the mesentery to prevent reperfusion injury

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain and distension. Imaging shows a sigmoid volvulus with signs of bowel ischemia. During surgery, you identify infarcted bowel. What is the best immediate step in management before detorsion of the volvulus?
questions.solution:
Intestinal ischemia

  • Intestinal ischemia/reperfusion injury is a significant risk when dealing with ischemic bowel.
  • Preventive measures include clamping the mesentery before detorsion to avoid the systemic release of inflammatory mediators.

Explanation of Options:

Option A: Administer IV antibiotics: Incorrect. Antibiotics may be part of the supportive care but do not address reperfusion injury prevention.

Option B: Proceed with detorsion of the volvulus: Incorrect. Immediate detorsion of ischemic bowel can lead to the release of inflammatory mediators, causing remote lung injury and other systemic complications.

Option C: Clamp the mesentery to prevent reperfusion injury: Correct. By clamping the mesentery, reperfusion injury is prevented until the bowel's viability is assessed and dealt with appropriately.

(D) Observe for spontaneous reperfusion: Incorrect. Allowing spontaneous reperfusion of infarcted bowel can cause significant inflammatory injury and should be avoided.

Key Points:

  • Viable intestine may regain function, while a non-viable intestine should be resected.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with a history of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding. He has a known history of diverticulosis. Endoscopic examination reveals inflammation in the sigmoid colon near diverticula, with rectal sparing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(A) Diverticular colitis: Correct. This is a clinicopathological entity distinct from IBD. It occurs in colonic segments affected by diverticula, and symptoms resemble IBD but are localized to areas with diverticula, often sparing the rectum.

(B) Ulcerative colitis: Incorrect. Ulcerative colitis typically involves continuous inflammation starting from the rectum and extending proximally, without sparing the rectum.

(C) Crohn's disease: Incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and typically shows skip lesions, which is not seen here.

(D) Radiation colitis: Incorrect. Radiation colitis occurs following radiation therapy, which the patient does not have a history of, and primarily affects areas within the radiation field.

Key Points:

  • Diverticular colitis should be differentiated from IBD to avoid unnecessary treatments. Rectal sparing is a clue to diverticular colitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of iron-deficiency anemia is diagnosed with carcinoma of the cecum. What is the most appropriate surgical treatment?
questions.solution:
• Right hemicolectomy is the treatment of choice for carcinoma of the cecum and ascending colon.
  • Extended right hemicolectomy is for transverse and splenic flexure cancers.
  • Left hemicolectomy is for descending colon and sigmoid cancers.

Explanation:

(A) Right hemicolectomy: Correct. Carcinoma of the cecum is treated with a right hemicolectomy, which involves resection of the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal transverse colon with regional lymphadenectomy.

(B) Extended right hemicolectomy: Incorrect. This is indicated for tumors of the transverse colon or splenic flexure, where a more extensive resection is required.

(C) Left hemicolectomy: Incorrect. This is used for cancers in the descending colon and sigmoid colon.

(D) Segmental resection: Incorrect. Segmental resections are generally not preferred for right-sided colon cancers, as a right hemicolectomy ensures adequate lymph node removal.

Key Points: Right hemicolectomy involves ligating the ileocolic artery and removing the right colon.
